sections.title: Overview
sections.content: The Maldives is a small island nation in South Asia, located in the Indian Ocean. It is famous for its crystal-clear waters, coral reefs, luxury resorts, and low-lying atolls.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Mal√© is the capital and most populous city of the Maldives, serving as the political, economic, and cultural center.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency of the Maldives is the Maldivian rufiyaa (MVR).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The official language is Dhivehi. English is widely used in tourism and business.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Maldivian cuisine is heavily based on seafood, coconut, and rice, with popular dishes such as mas huni, garudhiya, and fish curry.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: The Maldives consists of over 1,000 coral islands grouped into 26 atolls, making it one of the flattest and lowest countries in the world.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Maldivian culture is influenced by South Asian, Arab, and African traditions, with strong emphasis on Islam, community, and maritime life.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: Tourism is the backbone of the Maldivian economy, with activities such as snorkeling, diving, island hopping, and luxury resort stays.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: The Maldives is the lowest country in the world, with an average ground level of about 1.5 meters above sea level.

history.event: Early settlers arrived from the Indian subcontinent and Sri Lanka.
The Maldives converted to Islam, shaping its national identity.
The Portuguese briefly occupied the Maldives.
The Maldives became a British protectorate.
The Maldives gained independence from the United Kingdom.
